replies.msg:
CITY JOIN RACE FOR PAVON

Man City have entered the race to sign versatile Stuttgart defender Benjamin Pavard, says Suddeutsche Zeitung.

However, the France international is also being chased by the likes of Bayern Munich and Real Madrid.

MORNING HEADLINES

OK for those of you just joining us - firstly where have you been? - but here is a quick roundup of where we stand with some of the day's main transfer stories...

Sky Italy believe that Cristiano Ronaldo's proposed £88m switch from Real to Juve is progressing well

It's our understanding Arsenal are in talks to sign Sevilla midfielder Steven N'Zonzi

Our sources have told us West Ham are close to agreeing a deal for Jack Wilshere.
The midfielder is available on a free transfer after he left Arsenal at the end of his contract last week

We understand Wolves could be about to break their transfer record, having made a club-record bid of £16m for Man City midfielder Oleksandr Zinchenko

Gianluigi Buffon has joined PSG - The 40-year-old has signed a one-year deal with the option of a further 12 months

Manchester United have reportedly opted against pursuing a deal for Liverpool transfer target Nabil Fekir, according to the Manchester Evening News.

Lyon chief Jean-Michel Aulas recently revealed he had spoken to Jose Mourinho, but no deal is on the table from Man Utd.

åˆå¹è¿”fekir

Manchester United may get their ideal left-back next summer

Man Utd have prioritised signing a centre-back this summer but they have their ideal left-back in place next summer.

Jose Mourinho went largely unnoticed when he rocked up in Glasgow in March. There was no sighting at the airport or an appearance at Kelvingrove Art Gallery. The United boss was not even spotted as he made his way into Hampden Park at 7.30pm.

On the surface, there was a very innocent explanation for the Portuguese being in attendance for a meaningless friendly between Scotland and Costa Rica.

His protégé, Scott McTominay, who he would later hand his own personal gong at the club's award's night, was making his international debut but Mourinho will have been disappointed by the absence of one of the youngster's team-mates that night.

Kieran Tierney, who has been on Mourinho's radar for the majority of his reign at Old Trafford, pulled out with a calf injury in the run-up to the game - long after the United boss' travel arrangements had been made.

Club scouts have since been dispatched to watch Tierney, again, and the Celtic skipper is high up on the list of left-backs United have monitored since Mourinho took charge.

Why?

Despite being just 21 years of age, Tierney is a three-time title winner and has already captained both club and country. Although a natural left-back, he is also comfortable on the right or on the left of a three-man defence.

The Scotland international also fits the profile of target Mourinho has broadly looked at since taking charge. Those players, like Diogo Dalot, who are under 25 and will ironically reach their peaks under his successor.

Grounded, and level headed, Tierney has never once talked up interest from the Premier League as he lives his dream at a club he has spent 13 years with.

Interest from abroad has never affected his performances; in fact, Tierney has looked at home with the eyes of the world on him when playing in the Champions League, relishing that step up from Hamilton away and Dundee at home.

With five years left on his contact, he has been patient and will not leave Parkhead for any old opportunity in England. Nor will Celtic even consider opening talks for anything less than £25m.

And United are prepared to wait - for another year anyway - after again appearing to put off their left-back search.

You feel just as United were careful and considered to earmarking Fred as Michael Carrick's replacement - scouting him at all of Shakhtar's home games in April and May - they will follow suit when it comes to Ashley Young's eventual replacement.

Luke Shaw, of course, will get another chance on tour to stake his claim. The 22-year-old is into the final year of his United contract but has a fresh opportunity to make the left-back slot his own in the US with Young at the World Cup.

What Mourinho likes about Young, though, and why he came straight back into the team last season after serving a three-match ban, is his hunger and desire.

The veteran is still as driven as he was when he was a 21-year-old earning rave reviews at Watford. Coupled with his professionalism, that is a potent combination and why Young has reinvented himself as an international left-back in the space of just a year.

An intriguing dilemma awaits in the coming months. Regardless of his form, do United offer Shaw a new contract to protect his market value? Or would Shaw be prepared to reject it if he does not get the first-team assurances he needs?

One way or the other, you feel United will have the left-back they desire in a year's time. Whether that is a rejuvinated Shaw or a new signing like Tierney.
